coredata.dc:title: Highlighting the impact of cascade carrier testing in cystic fibrosis families

L'Hostis, Carine
Audrézet, Marie-Pierre
Rault, Gilles

Bernard, Rémy
Parent, Philippe
Blayau, Martine
Schmitt, Sébastien
Génin, Emmanuelle
Férec, Claude
Scotet, Virginie
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Background Cascade carrier testing within cystic fibrosis (CF) affected families offers relatives of CF patients the opportunity to know their status regarding the mutation that segregates within their family, and thus to make informed reproductive choices. As an Australian study has recently shown that this test seemed underused, we searched to assess uptake of this test in a European area where CF is common, and to report its public health implications.
Methods This study relied on 40 CF-affected families from western Brittany, France. Investigations included drawing of family trees and registration of carrier tests performed in those families.
Results Of the 459 relatives eligible for testing, 185 were tested, leading to an adjusted uptake rate of testing of 40.7% (95% CI: [34.1%; 47.3%]). The main predictors for having testing were being female (p=0.031) and having a high prior risk (p<0.001). Planning a pregnancy or expecting a child (reported in at least 38.4% of tested relatives) also appeared critical in choosing to be tested. Overall, carrier testing allowed to reassure more than 1/4 of the relatives and to detect five new 1-in-4 at-risk couples who then requested prenatal diagnosis.
Conclusions This observational study assesses, for first time in Europe, uptake of CF cascade carrier testing within CF families, which is a critical tool to reassure non-carriers and to detect early new at-risk couples.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Flow chart of the inclusion/exclusion criteria.
A. Representation of time taken to be tested for relatives.

Time taken to be tested represents the difference between the date of testing and the date of family mutation identification (or the date at adulthood (18years) for relatives who were minor when the mutation was identified).
B. Representation of age of relatives at testing.

It should be noted that testing was performed before the age of 18years in 21 relatives, either because CF was suspected in siblings, or because testing was performed before the 1994 French Bioethics Laws that govern genetic testing management and prohibit testing of minor children.
Overview and public health implications of carrier testing in the 40 participating CF families.
Main features of the CF patients enrolled in the study (n=40) and comparison with the characteristics of the patients born over the same period who did not participate.
Main characteristics of the eligible relatives (excluding parents) (n=459).

row.entry: Status of relative at time of mutation identification (n=459)

Mode of diagnosis of the CF patient (n=459)

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Proportion of non-parent relatives tested according to various factors, and results of the univariate and multivariate logistic regression models (adjusted for clustering) searching for predictors of uptake of cascade carrier testing.

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: OR: odds ratio; CI: confidence interval.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: GEE analysis was performed using an exchangeable correlation structure (as it was assumed that all correlations were equal). The “logit” link was used for identification of predictors.
n: number of eligible relatives tested/number of eligible relatives.
Odds ratio not estimated due to the very small number of participants in that group.

head.ce:title: Highlighting the impact of cascade carrier testing in cystic fibrosis families

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Cascade carrier testing within cystic fibrosis (CF) affected families offers relatives of CF patients the opportunity to know their status regarding the mutation that segregates within their family, and thus to make informed reproductive choices. As an Australian study has recently shown that this test seemed underused, we searched to assess uptake of this test in a European area where CF is common, and to report its public health implications.
This study relied on 40 CF-affected families from western Brittany, France. Investigations included drawing of family trees and registration of carrier tests performed in those families.

Of the 459 relatives eligible for testing, 185 were tested, leading to an adjusted uptake rate of testing of 40.7% (95% CI: [34.1%; 47.3%]). The main predictors for having testing were being female (p=0.031) and having a high prior risk (p<0.001). Planning a pregnancy or expecting a child (reported in at least 38.4% of tested relatives) also appeared critical in choosing to be tested. Overall, carrier testing allowed to reassure more than 1/4 of the relatives and to detect five new 1-in-4 at-risk couples who then requested prenatal diagnosis.

This observational study assesses, for first time in Europe, uptake of CF cascade carrier testing within CF families, which is a critical tool to reassure non-carriers and to detect early new at-risk couples.

ce:section.ce:para: Despite great improvements in disease management that allow more than half the patients to reach adulthood, cystic fibrosis (CF) remains a life-threatening condition [1]. The identification in 1989 of the gene responsible for this autosomal recessive disease (the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene) [2–4] made possible genetic diagnosis for CF patients, and thus cascade carrier testing for family members.

Cascade carrier testing offers relatives of CF patients (who have an increased risk of being themselves carriers of the mutation that segregates within their family) the opportunity to know their status regarding the family mutation. The term “cascade” reflects the fact that the test stems from an index case: it is first offered to the relatives of the CF patient and, in a second time, to their spouses if the relatives are found carrier. The ultimate goal of this test is to reassure non-carrier relatives, but also to allow for early detection of couples with a 1-in-4 risk of having a CF child, who will then be able to make informed reproductive choices (such as use of prenatal diagnosis). In the absence of mutation-specific therapy for all patients, cascade carrier testing within families remains therefore a major prevention tool in the context of serious genetic diseases [5–8].

Cascade carrier testing should not be confused with population-based carrier screening that aims to identify all CF carriers in a given population. Such programs are undertaken in some regions around the world, as in Australia, in the Veneto region in Italy or in the US [9–11].

To date, few studies have been published on cascade carrier testing within CF families [12–18], and most of them reported results of active programs (in regard to information or recruitment of relatives). Globally, relatively low rates of testing uptake have been observed in relatives of affected patients. In an observational study conducted in Victoria (Australia) in 2010, McClaren et al. [18] reported an uptake rate of testing of 11.8% in relatives of screened children born during 2000–2004. To our knowledge, no measure of uptake of cascade carrier testing in CF families has been performed in France or in Europe, from an observational study design based on the examination of clinical practices.

The present study aims to assess the uptake of cascade carrier testing in relatives of CF patients born over a 25-year period (1980–2004) in a district of western Brittany (Finistère, France), where CF is particularly common [19]. It determines the proportion of relatives tested, identifies factors influencing the choice of having testing, and reports the public health implications of this test.

We conducted an observational retrospective study in the district of Finistère, an area of 900,000 inhabitants in western Brittany (France) where the incidence of CF is high (~1/2500 live births) [19,20]. The high mutation detection rate obtained in that population shortly after the discovery of the CFTR gene [21] has enabled clinicians to offer early an efficient and efficacious testing process to identify carriers in CF families.

When CF is diagnosed in a child, his parents have the opportunity to meet a genetic counselor, who explains the disease, but also the implications of the diagnosis for future pregnancies and the availability of cascade carrier testing for their relatives. As until recently the transmission of the genetic information within families could exclusively be done by the parents of the CF child, they were invited to inform their relatives about their possibility of having testing. A recent change in French law henceforth allows GPs to directly inform relatives of CF patients on their risk and the possibility of getting tested.

Cascade carrier testing, which is offered during a genetic counseling session, consists first in determining whether the relative does or not carry the CFTR mutation that segregates within his/her family. If the relative appears to be non-carrier of this mutation, the study is stopped and he/she can be reassured regarding his/her offspring. Conversely, if the relative is found to be carrier, a CFTR gene analysis is proposed to his/her spouse. The guidelines are to use of a commercial kit (of 30 mutations) that enables to detect 85% of the CFTR mutations in the French population. If no mutation is identified in the spouse by this strategy, a residual risk of CF is given to the couple. On the other hand, if one mutation is also identified in the partner, the couple has a 1-in-4 risk of having a CF child. Genetic counseling is then offered to the couple who may opt for prenatal diagnosis for current or future pregnancies. Such tests are covered by the French Health Insurance.
This study was conducted from families of CF patients born in Finistère over the 1980–2004 period. It was approved by the ethical committee of the University Hospital of Brest.

The identification of patients eligible for the study was facilitated because a registry of CF patients born in Brittany since the 1970s was set up several years ago [19], and because Brittany was a pioneer back in 1989 in setting up a CF newborn screening (NBS) program [22].

The flow chart of the inclusion/exclusion criteria in the study is presented in Fig. 1 . Over the study period, 128 CF patients were born in the district of Finistère. Nine of them were de facto ineligible for the study: two were adopted and seven already had a CF-affected sibling born during the study period (only one patient per family, the first diagnosed, could be included). In all, 119 patients were eligible for the study, but only 109 could be informed of the study as eight were lost to follow up and two had a difficult family context. At the end of the inclusion period (Dec. 31st, 2014), 40 families agreed to participate in the study.

A two-step strategy was used to collect data required for the study:
1)
First, patients (or their parents) were asked to fill out a consent form and to provide a family tree (limited to all descendants and spouses of the grandparents of the enrolled CF patient) that was reconstructed using the GenoPro® software (v. 2.0.1.6).
2)
Thereafter, we collected results of all the CFTR gene studies performed in those families from the three molecular genetics laboratories of Brittany (University Hospitals of Brest, Rennes and Nantes) and from the medical genetics unit at the Hospital of Brest.
Both data sources (family structures and gene testing results) were then compared.
Statistical analyses were performed using SAS® software (v. 9.2) and the significance level was set at 5%.

First, we described the characteristics of the patients who participated in the study and assessed the sample representativeness. We then described the family structure and the relatives' characteristics, and estimated the frequency of uptake of carrier testing (with its 95% confidence interval [CI]). This frequency corresponded to the proportion of relatives tested among the eligible ones. To be eligible for testing, relatives had to be 18years or older at the time of the family's entry into the study, to be alive at the time of molecular diagnosis of the CF patient, to reside in one of the four districts of Brittany (Finistère, Côtes-d'Armor, Morbihan and Ille-et-Vilaine), and not prenatally tested (Supplementary material 1). Afterwards, we searched for the predictors of uptake of testing and investigated, using logistic regression, the association between the status of eligible relatives (tested versus untested) and various factors (such as gender, degree of kinship, etc.). Crude and adjusted odds ratios (OR) with their 95% CI were estimated. We also studied the time taken to complete the test, as well as the age of relatives when tested. Finally, we assessed the public health impact of carrier testing within families by determining the number of relatives/couples reassured, the number of relatives identified as carrying the family mutation, the number of 1-in-4 at risk couples detected, the number of prenatal diagnoses subsequently performed, the number of CF-fetuses identified, and the number of medical pregnancy terminations performed afterwards.

It is important to note that parents were excluded from most analyses because they are obligate carriers who usually choose to be tested. Moreover, estimation of uptake rate and search for predictors were conducted using generalized estimating equations (GEE) [18,23] that took into account clustering/correlation within families (i.e., the fact that an individual belonging to a family in which many relatives have been tested is himself more likely to request testing).

Our study was carried out from 40 patients whose baseline characteristics are summarized in Table 1 . Of them, 23 (57.5%) were females and 32 (80.0%) were alive at the time of inclusion with a mean age of 20.0years (SD=6.7). All patients had two severe CF-causing mutations, except one who carried a mild mutation (p.Arg347His) (Supplementary material 2). Globally, the CF patients who participated in the study (n=40) did not differ from those who did not (n=79).

The 40 participating families represented a total of 1301 individuals, including 80 parents, 955 relatives, 3 non-genetic relatives (adoptions) and 263 spouses. The mean number of relatives per family was 23.9 (range: [5; 62]).

Among the 955 relatives (excluding parents), 459 (48.1%) were found eligible for testing (i.e., 11.5 per family). Their characteristics are summarized in Table 2 . Among them, 58.6% had a 1/2 prior risk of being a carrier (i.e., uncles, aunts or grandparents, n=269), 34.2% had a 1/4 prior risk (i.e., cousins, n=157), 4.1% a 2/3 prior risk (i.e., siblings, n=19), and finally, 3.1% a 1/8 prior risk (i.e., children of cousins, n=14).
The main reason for ineligibility was being under 18years at the time of inclusion (68.1%).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Assessment of uptake of cascade carrier testing
ce:section.ce:para: Among the 459 eligible relatives, 185 (40.3%) chose to do the test, what corresponds, on average, to 4.6 relatives tested per family. The uptake rate of testing varies from one family to another, and ranged from 0.0% (in four families) to 92.3%. When adjusting for family effect, the uptake rate of testing was estimated at 40.7% (95% CI: [34.1%; 47.3%]), and raised to 48.8% (95% CI: [42.7%; 54.8%]) when taking into account the parents.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Predictors of uptake of cascade carrier testing
ce:section.ce:para: We then aimed at identifying the predictors of uptake of testing. Table 3 shows that the uptake of testing was mainly determined by female gender and by having a high prior risk of being carrier of the family mutation. Indeed, the uptake rate was 1.5 times higher in women than men (46.1% vs. 34.5% - adjusted OR=1.52; 95% CI: [1.04; 2.23]; p=0.031). It also increased with the degree of kinship, from 21.7% in first cousins to 89.5% in siblings. Overall, compared with relatives having a 1/4 prior risk, the uptake rate was 30.1 times higher in relatives with a 2/3 prior risk (p<0.001), and 3.6 times higher in relatives with a 1/2 prior risk (p=0.005). It is also important to note that close to 40% (71/185) of the eligible relatives who were tested, declared having a planned or an ongoing pregnancy at time of testing.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Time taken to perform the test and age at testing
Time taken to perform the test (Fig. 2a)
ce:section.ce:para: Most of eligible relatives (excluding parents) did the test shortly after the identification of the family mutation (45.0% within the first year). Overall, the median time taken to complete the test was 1.4years (interquartile range: [0.3; 6.2]).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Age of eligible relatives at time of testing (Fig. 2b)
ce:section.ce:para: The median age at testing was 31.2years (interquartile range: [25.1; 47.0]). Two peaks were nevertheless observed: one in the 25–35 age group (44.4%), which includes the average age at first child, and another one in the 45–55 age group (17.2%), corresponding to post-reproductive ages, where the knowledge of the genetic status may be more useful to offspring.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Public health implications of cascade carrier testing
ce:section.ce:para: Finally, we reported the impact of cascade carrier testing within the studied families (Fig. 3 ). Among the 185 relatives tested, 98 (53.0%) were identified carriers of the family mutation. Among their tested partners (n=65), five were also found carriers of one CFTR mutation, resulting in the identification of five new 1-in-4 at risk couples within these families. These couples benefited from prenatal diagnosis for eight subsequent pregnancies; five CF-affected fetuses were found and pregnancies terminated.

Moreover, cascade carrier testing made it possible to give reassurance to 87 tested relatives (who were shown to be non-carriers of the family mutation), and 60 couples (for whom the spouse of the carrier relatives was negative). In addition, 160 other relatives who were not tested (40 eligible and 120 ineligible) could be deduced non-carriers of the family mutation based on the information obtained from tested relatives. Indeed, the descendants of an individual who was found to be a non-carrier of the family mutation are de facto non-carriers of that mutation, and may be reassured regarding that mutation. Overall cascade carrier testing showed that over a quarter of the relatives were non-carriers of the family mutation (n=247, 25.9%): one-third through testing (n=87, 35.2%) and two-thirds by inference (n=160, 64.8%).

This observational study reports the first experience of one European area regarding uptake of cascade carrier testing within CF families. It shows a particularly high rate of test uptake in relatives of patients born in western Brittany over a 25-year period (40.7%). The public health impact of cascade carrier testing was also studied and we found that, besides the identification of numerous carriers and the detection of five new 1-in-4 at risk couples, the test was also useful at reassuring about one quarter of the relatives who were non-carrier of the family mutation. Furthermore, this study confirms that women and relatives with higher prior risks are more inclined to have testing. It also shows that having a planned or an ongoing pregnancy is a key element in making the decision to make the test. This is consistent with the observed median age at testing (31.2years), which is close to the average age at first child in France (28.8years in 2013 — http://www.insee.fr). It should have been great to assess if the severity of the genotype in the CF-affected member may had an influence on the uptake rate. Unfortunately, this was not feasible in our study as among the 40 enrolled CF patients, only one was carrier of a mild CFTR genotype.

Our study also reveals that the uptake rate of testing is particularly high among grandparents (38.7%), who are a key point in the genealogical structure. Knowing their genetic status can allow them to share this information with their own siblings/offspring who may be reassured when they are found non-carriers. This avoids numerous testing in the progeny.

Western Brittany is an ideal place in which to conduct this survey because CF is particularly common in this area [19]. A NBS program has been in place for over 25years [22], and since 1992, a very high CFTR mutation detection rate (>98%) was reached in that population [21] facilitating early the possibility of efficient cascade carrier testing for families in our region. Moreover, its population is particularly aware of CF and mobilized against it since the early 1990s. All this contributes to explain the high uptake rate we observed.

Regarding sample size, our study relied on a non-neglect number of families (40 versus 30 in the Australian study) and we ensured that the enrolled patients were representative of the target population. As our study was performed on a panel of families, it was not possible to measure the overall impact of cascade carrier testing on the disease incidence over the studied period. This was nevertheless already assessed by our team in a previous study devoted to prenatal diagnosis, which highlighted that ~1/5 of prenatal diagnoses were consecutive to cascade carrier testing [24]. It is important to keep in mind that, if this test was initially offered to relatives of CF patients, it could thereafter be proposed to relatives of carriers identified through NBS programs [25].

A weakness of our study was our inability to involve all the French genetic laboratories (both public and private, n=36), and therefore have information on test status for all the relatives. Beyond the genetic laboratory of Finistère (which has great expertise in CF and is one of the four reference laboratories for the French CF NBS program), we had access to data from the two other genetic laboratories in the Brittany area. To overcome a possible bias, the relatives who lived outside of Brittany were excluded from the calculations (they represented only a small proportion (~20%) of the non-eligible relatives).

Cascade carrier testing is effective in other genetic disorders such as Huntington's disease, beta-thalassemia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy or fragile X syndrome [6,8,26], but it appears that the majority of at-risk family members do not have genetic testing [26]. In CF, the first experience regarding cascade carrier testing was reported in 1993 by Turner et al. [12], who described the tests performed in an extended Australian family (estimated uptake rate: 21.2%). One year later, Super et al. [13] reported the acceptability and efficiency of active screening for carriers in more than 600 British CF families. They found an increase in the number of tests performed following the start of an active information program, but the study design made it impossible to estimate the uptake rate.

Several studies have focused on the uptake of cascade carrier testing, but they were mainly based on active information or recruitment strategies [12,15–17]. Moreover, these studies relied on heterogeneous designs, including various populations (relatives only, relatives and partners, various degrees relatives, etc) contacted in different ways (letter, phone call, educational courses, etc). The uptake rate was clearly higher in studies based on active programs (from ~20 to ~70%) [12,15–17] than in observational ones (~10%) [14,18].

Similar to the Australian study by McClaren et al. [18] (carried out from patients screened at birth in Victoria from 2000 to 2004) and the Canadian one by Surh et al. [14] (conduced in Ottawa from 1990 to 1992), our study is an observational study based on the examination of clinical practices, without any interventional policy. However, we found an uptake rate higher than those previously reported (40.7% versus<12% in Victoria and Ottawa). This difference can mainly be explained by divergences in family structures (families less extended in our study, leading to greater proportions of relatives with high prior risk), study durations (our study was longer and therefore allows a greater proportion of siblings with high prior risk to be eligible for testing) and in population awareness. Even though uptake rates were different, the uptake predictors we found were consistent with those reported by the Australian team (with similar odds ratios) [18]. The fact that women are more inclined to make the test corroborates the gender effect found in other genetic disorders [26–29].

Regarding sociological aspects, several authors have noted that, in relatives, disease knowledge levels [30], perceived genetic risk and perceived burden of having a CF child are highly relevant at the time of making the decision to be tested [15,31,32]. It is also essential to emphasize the importance of the dissemination of genetic information within families. Information and testing enable early detection of potential new 1-in-4 at risk couples, but above all, provide reassurance to non-carrier relatives and their offspring. This avoids realization of unnecessary genetic tests. The role of patients is substantial, as they are the first stage in the transmission of genetic information to relatives. Communication should certainly be easier since set up of NBS programs and multidisciplinary disease management in CF centers. The need to provide support to parents to facilitate the information transmission appears crucial [33]. Recent changes in French laws that now allow GPs to inform relatives of CF patients might have an impact on the uptake rate of testing in the coming years.

After testing, couples for whom both members are found carriers have to cope with the impact of such a result on their reproductive behavior. In the late 1990s, Henneman et al. [34] showed that most couples report shock, more anxiety (especially when pregnancy is ongoing) and difficulties in disclosing the results to family members. However, most couples did not regret the choice to have testing. It would be interesting to reassess if such perceptions have changed over the years.

Investigating the reasons for not testing in relatives of 30 CF children diagnosed through newborn screening, McClaren et al. [33] recently showed that the main reasons mentioned by relatives are irrelevant perception of the test's usefulness, lack of awareness of the possibility to do the test and test considered as something to do later.

In conclusion, this study provides an overview of the uptake of cascade carrier testing in CF families in western Brittany. It also highlights the public health implications of this test, which is a useful tool to reassure relatives/couples and for early detection of new at-risk couples. Further sociological studies are needed to more finely investigate motivations and reluctance to do the test. Besides CF, this study provides some important insights on the population acceptability of genetic testing in general that could be useful for making decisions regarding the release of incidental findings when next-generation sequencing studies are performed.
None.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We thank all the patients and families who participated in this study, as well as the teams and physicians from the CF centers who contributed data: Drs. A. Dirou, J. Le Bihan, S. Ramel, G. Rault and K. Revert (Roscoff), Drs. MR. Munck and I. Frachon (Brest), Drs. R. Bernard and P. Vic (Quimper), Dr. R. Chiron (Montpellier), Dr. A. Dumonceaux (Ile de la Réunion), Dr. A. Houzel (Dijon) and Dr. C. Thumerelle (Lille). We also thank B.J. McClaren and O.C. Ukoumunne from the Murdoch Childrens Research Institute in Victoria, Australia for their invaluable help with GEE analysis.

This study was funded by a grant from the French CF Association “Vaincre La Mucoviscidose” (RC20120600694 and RC20130500859) and by the Association Gaëtan Saleün “Don du Sang et Recherche en Génétique”. The funders have no role in data analysis, interpretation or in the writing of the manuscript.
